item.title: Venezuela Updates: U.S. Forces Seize Two Tankers; Rubio Lays Out Plan for American Control
item.description: After the secretary of state unveiled a proposal for managing Venezuela and the U.S. forces boarded a Russian-flagged tanker and a second ship, President Trump had a phone call with President Gustavo Petro of Colombia amid escalating tensions between the two leaders.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Europe Tries to Come to Terms With Trump’s Intervention in Venezuela
item.description: Needing U.S. support to fend off Russia in Ukraine, European leaders have been cautious about criticizing President Trump on Greenland, Iran, Venezuela and much else.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit preparing to fire at Russian positions near the frontline city of Pokrovsk in the Donbas region last month.

item.title: Buy Greenland? Take It? Why? An Old Pact Already Gives Trump a Free Hand.
item.description: Analysts say the Cold War agreement allows the president to increase the American military presence almost at will.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Amelia Nierenberg and Maya Tekeli
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remnants of an American air base on Greenland called Bluie East Two, which was built during World War II.

item.title: Maduro Is Gone, but Repression in Venezuela Has Intensified
item.description: Security forces have boarded buses, searched phones and interrogated people, looking for evidence that they welcomed the capture of Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

item.title: Reshuffle at Ukraine’s Intelligence Agencies Draws Criticism
item.description: Some ask whether the shake-up risks disrupting the agencies’ operations and is political in nature.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Kyrylo Budanov in Kyiv, Ukraine, in 2024. He is now the presidential chief of staff, after having served as head of military intelligence.

item.title: Yemen Separatist Leader Refuses to Attend Talks, Deepening Saudi Arabia-UAE Clash
item.description: Invited to Saudi Arabia for talks, dozens of Yemeni separatist officials went incommunicado on Wednesday as the conflict in their country took a sharp twist.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Aidarous al-Zubaidi, the leader of the Southern Transitional Council, a separatist group, in 2023 at a Yemeni community event in Queens, N.Y.

item.title: After Trump’s Military Victory in Venezuela, Cuba’s Economy Is in ‘Freefall’
item.description: With widespread power outages, medicine shortages and rising food prices, experts say Cuba’s economy has never been worse, with the crisis coming just as the supply of Venezuelan oil is threatened.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams and Frances Robles
item.media:description: Cooking soup over an open fire in Havana after the failure of a major power plant in October.

item.title: Clashes Between Syrian Government and Kurdish-Led Militia Restart After Deaths
item.description: Fighting in the city of Aleppo resumed as talks to integrate the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces into the national military appear to have stalled.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: A girl at a hospital in Aleppo, Syria, who was wounded during clashes between the Syrian Army and the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces.

item.title: Hundreds of Tourists on Yemeni Island Caught Up in Saudi-U.A.E. Rift
item.description: Around 600 foreigners have been stranded on Socotra as clashes on mainland Yemen halted flights, turning the nature sanctuary and tourist spot into a geopolitical trap.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar
item.media:description: Tourists outside a hotel on the island of Socotra, Yemen, on Monday.

item.title: Displaced Palestinians in Egypt Await Reopening of Gaza Border
item.description: Tens of thousands of Palestinians in Egypt face an uncertain future as they navigate obstacles to staying in the country and returning home to Gaza. The New York Times spoke to a family that remains separated despite a truce in the territory.
item.dc:creator: Alex Pena, Saher Alghorra, Monika Cvorak and Jon Hazell

item.title: Russia Sends Naval Vessel to Escort Oil Tanker U.S. Is Pursuing
item.description: The development deepens the confrontation over the tanker formerly known as the Bella 1, which the United States wants to seize but which Russia has sought to protect.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella, Nicholas Nehamas and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The oil tanker Marinera, formerly known as Bella 1, at the Singapore Strait in March. Russia has dispatched at least one naval vessel to meet and escort the tanker.

item.title: The Players to Know in Venezuela’s Leadership
item.description: Since President Trump deposed Nicolás Maduro, his entrenched web of loyalists has appeared to remain intact. Here’s a look at some of the most influential.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s vice president, was sworn in as interim leader on Monday.

item.title: China Touts Hainan, Its Duty-Free Island, Amid $1 Trillion Trade Surplus
item.description: Policies meant to lure importers to Hainan, a resort island off China’s coast, signal an opening up, Beijing says. One expert calls it a “bait and switch.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at an exhibition center promoting Hainan’s investment opportunities. The island is promoting itself as the world’s largest “free trade port.”

item.title: Israel Tells Doctors Without Borders to End Its Work in Gaza
item.description: The move against the medical aid group enforces policies limiting criticism of Israel’s conduct in the war and requiring personal details about Gazan employees.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger, Aaron Boxerman and Saher Alghorra
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times

item.title: A Majority of Venezuelans Struggle to Pay for Food, Poll Shows
item.description: A new Gallup survey found that more than half of Venezuelans reported struggling to afford food last year, with economic hardship reaching even the wealthy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: At a street market in Caracas, the capital of Venezuela, in October.

item.title: Why Russian Tourists Are Flocking to Southern China’s Beaches
item.description: Russians find a refuge on the beaches of Sanya from sanctions and “sideways looks,” toasting the New Year beside a Chinese nuclear submarine base.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Gilles Sabrié

item.title: When It Comes to Russia, Trump Navigates Conflicting Goals
item.description: President Trump’s efforts to court President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia are rife with contradictions about stability and displays of American power.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin in Alaska last August. Mr. Trump’s focus on strength has magnified tensions with Russia in regions like Latin America, where Mr. Putin has sought to extend his influence

item.title: Hoisting Russian Flags, ‘Shadow Fleet’ Edges Into the Light
item.description: The Marinera, which was seized by the U.S., isn’t the only ship from the “shadow fleet” of oil tankers to switch lately to a Russian identity, seeking protection.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Michael Schwirtz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Vesa Moilanen/Lehtikuva, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Eagle S, an oil tanker, last January after Finnish commandos commandeered it over suspicions that it had deliberately cut vital undersea cables. The authorities said the ship appeared to belong to Russia’s shadow fleet.

item.title: What Is the UNFCCC and Why Is the U.S. Pulling Out?
item.description: The Trump administration said Wednesday that the United States was withdrawing from 66 international agreements, including a major climate change treaty.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, or UNFCCC, is the treaty that sets a legal framework for international negotiations to address climate change.

item.title: Protests Spread in Iran, and Crackdowns Escalate
item.description: Bazaars were shuttered and demonstrators met with violence from security forces amid rising anger about the country’s dire economic situation.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: An image taken from social media shows Iranian security forces using tear gas to disperse protesters at the Tehran bazaar on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump and Colombian President Speak by Phone Amid Escalating Tensions
item.description: The American president said a White House visit with Gustavo Petro was being arranged by the secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump returning to the White House on Sunday. Mr. Trump said he was looking forward to a meeting with Colombia’s president at the White House soon.

item.title: Trump Pulls Out of Global Climate Treaty
item.description: The action could make it more difficult for a future administration to rejoin the Paris climate accord, the agreement among most nations to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: President Trump addressing the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York last year.

item.title: What Are ‘Ghost Fleet’ Ships?
item.description: Also known as “dark fleet” or “shadow fleet” ships, the vessels use murky tactics to transport oil in violation of sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: An image from video footage released by the U.S. military purporting to show the seizure of the oil tanker M Sophia in the Caribbean Sea on Wednesday.

item.title: Amid heavy security, a tentative return of street life in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Vendors and shoppers at a street market in the Petare neighborhood of Caracas, Venezuela, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S., Cementing Control on Venezuelan Oil, Seizes Russian-Flagged Tanker
item.description: The vessel was one of two taken into American custody as the Trump administration said it was executing a “deal to take all the oil.”
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Michael Levenson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The oil tanker Marinera, formerly known as Bella 1, at sea in the Singapore Strait last year.

item.title: During Maduro Raid in Venezuela, a Close Call for Helicopters and Trump’s Plan
item.description: As a damaged U.S. helicopter struggled to stay aloft over Venezuela’s capital, the success of the entire operation hung in the balance.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Senate Republicans Push Back on Trump’s Aspirations to Seize Greenland
item.description: Opposition was stacking up to the United States buying the semiautonomous island or taking it by force.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, background, looking toward Senator Tim Kaine, Democrat of Virginia, at the Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: Lawmakers Split After Classified Briefings on Venezuela
item.description: Republicans praised what they characterized as a narrow and well-executed plan, while Democrats expressed alarm, warning that the mission was vaguely defined.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio speaking at the Capitol on Wednesday after a Senate briefing on operations in Venezuela.

item.title: All Eyes on the U.S. in 2026
item.description: Our reporters in Washington tell us what they’re watching from the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: U.S. Seizes Oil Tanker and Boards Another Amid Tensions With Russia
item.description: The first ship had eluded the Coast Guard after being stopped on its way to pick up oil in Venezuela. U.S. forces also boarded another tanker in international waters near the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

item.title: An emergency order from the Venezuelan government appears to criminalize support for the U.S. attack.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro was escorted off a helicopter on Monday to be taken to the federal court appearance in Manhattan.

item.title: U.S. Pressures Venezuela to Expel Advisers From Cuba, China, Russia and Iran
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio was said to have listed the Trump administration’s demands to Venezuela’s new leader, Delcy Rodríguez, in a classified meeting Monday with senior congressional leaders.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio at the Capitol on Monday. He spoke at a classified meeting with senior congressional leaders.

item.title: Latin American countries condemn the U.S. at the Organization of American States meeting.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: Albert Ramdin, secretary general of the Organization of American States, speaking at an emergency meeting in Washington, on Tuesday.

item.title: Rubio Tells Lawmakers Trump Wants to Buy Greenland
item.description: President Trump has said since his first term that he wants to acquire Greenland, and he asked aides for an updated plan on Monday. European leaders reject the president’s assertions.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A former radar station in eastern Greenland. President Trump has long said he wants to acquire the territory.

item.title: The Trump administration covets Venezuela’s oil reserves, and the implications for the planet could be serious.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuela has about 17 percent of the world’s known oil reserves.

item.title: 2 Caribbean Nations Agree to Host People Seeking Asylum in U.S.
item.description: The island nations of Dominica, and Antigua and Barbuda, recently targeted by Washington, said they had reached deals to receive asylum seekers turned away by the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Prime minister Gaston Browne of Antigua and Barbuda addressing the United Nations General Assembly in New York in September.

item.title: Three Views on What 2026 Might Bring
item.description: Our reporters on the ground tell us what they’re watching in Ukraine, the Middle East and China.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: The village of Mezhova, Ukraine, in December.

item.title: Europe Rallies for Greenland as Trump’s Threats Continue
item.description: The show of solidarity comes as President Trump, emboldened by his capture of Nicolás Maduro from Venezuela, has suggested he could take action against other countries.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, right, greeting Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark before a summit of European leaders at the Élysée Palace in Paris on Tuesday.

item.title: Winter Weather Snarls Travel in Amsterdam, Brussels and Other European Cities
item.description: Ice and winds disrupted airports and caused car accidents, with many travelers forced to sleep at an airport in Amsterdam. The disruptions are expected to continue through Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz, Jeanna Smialek, Ségolène Le Stradic, Judson Jones and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Travelers at Amsterdam Airport Schiphol looking for updates on delayed and canceled flights on Tuesday.

item.title: After Maduro’s Ouster, Marco Rubio Faces the Challenge of Running Venezuela
item.description: The secretary of state helped steer President Trump to attacking Venezuela and seizing Nicolás Maduro, and now aims to force the country to give U.S. companies access to its oil.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A poor outcome in Venezuela could jeopardize Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s chances at higher office.

item.title: Maduro Invokes Prisoner-of-War Status, Echoing Panama’s Noriega
item.description: The argument worked for Manuel Antonio Noriega, who wore a uniform at trial and received special P.O.W. privileges after his conviction.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: Supporters of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela demonstrating in Caracas, Venezuela, on Sunday. Mr. Maduro was seized by U.S. forces on Saturday.

item.title: The Unanswered Questions About Venezuela’s Environmental Future
item.description: The Trump administration has made no secret that it covets Venezuela’s oil reserves. What happens next could have serious implications for the planet.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Petroleos de Venezuela oil rigs on Maracaibo Lake in Cabimas, in the country’s northwest, in 2022.

item.title: Iran Says It’s Investigating Violence at Weekend Protests
item.description: Rights groups accuse security forces of killing protesters and storming a hospital in the province of Ilam. State media claimed that some protesters were armed.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Arijeta Lajka

item.title: Maduro’s Nike Tech Sweatsuit Was Bound to Become a Meme
item.description: When President Trump shared an unverified photo of Nicolás Maduro in U.S. custody, a corner of the internet followed a familiar playbook for newsmaking images: Talk about the clothes.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher

item.title: European Allies Agree to Key Security Provisions for Ukraine
item.description: Britain and France firmed up a postwar troop commitment in Ukraine, though Russia has said it will reject any deal that allows NATO-country forces in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Presidents Emmanuel Macron of France and Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine arrived on Tuesday in Paris for the latest round of talks on Ukraine’s future.

item.title: Syria and Israel Revive Security Talks Mediated by the U.S.
item.description: The talks, in Paris, are the latest bid to reduce tensions between two longtime enemies. A deal would help both curry favor with the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: A member of Syria’s security forces in September near the Golan Heights, which is the most enduring point of contention between Syria and Israel.

item.title: Can Venezuela’s New Leader Keep the U.S. Happy and Her Elites in Line?
item.description: As the country’s status quo abruptly shifts, experts say maintaining a coalition is crucial for political survival.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez moments before being sworn in as Venezuela’s president in Caracas, on Monday.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Daniel Victor

item.title: Optimism About Nuclear Energy Is Rising Again. Will It Last?
item.description: Companies like Kairos Power are building new types of reactors with the encouragement of the Trump administration, but their success is far from assured.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Ramsay de Give for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kairos Power, which is developing a new kind of nuclear reactor, makes many of its parts at a facility in Albuquerque, N.M.

item.title: Swiss Bar Hit by Deadly Fire Was Not Inspected for 6 Years, Authorities Say
item.description: Officials in Crans-Montana, the Swiss alpine resort town where a bar fire killed 40 people last week, are facing growing accusations of lax oversight.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police outside the sealed-off Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana, Switzerland, last week.

item.title: Why Israel Is Divided Over How to Investigate Oct. 7 Failures
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has proposed a commission with members chosen in a way that departs from existing law.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A memorial in 2025 on the grounds of the Nova music festival, which was attacked by Hamas and other militants on Oct. 7, 2023.

item.title: How the ‘Donroe Doctrine’ Reinforces Xi’s Vision of Power in Asia
item.description: The U.S. assault on Venezuela points to a world where big powers seek to call the shots in their regions, an idea Beijing knows well.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, with President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, in Caracas in 2014.

item.title: Maduro’s Gesture Was Not Just a Peace Sign
item.description: The captured authoritarian leader flashed a symbol that many took to be a defiant peace sign. Loyal lawmakers repeated the gesture at a session in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:description: Venezuela’s leader, Nicolás Maduro, arriving in New York, on Saturday.

item.title: Venezuela’s Machado Praises Trump in Fox News Interview
item.description: María Corina Machado, the Venezuelan opposition leader, offered to share her Nobel Peace Prize with President Trump. He has refused to back her.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado at a rally during the country’s presidential election in 2024.
